Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, my stepdad passing the salad while my stepsister chatted about her day. My phone buzzed in my pocket—again. I knew what it was: the post I’d made about climate justice was exploding online. Notifications kept popping up, people asking questions, sharing their own stories, and waiting for me to respond. This was the moment I’d been working toward as an activist, the chance to educate and connect with so many people at once. But here, in this dining room, my stepmom was watching me, hoping I’d join in the laughter and stories, not stare at my phone. I could feel the weight of their expectations—be present, be part of the family, make this new arrangement work. But my activist side screamed that I couldn’t let this opportunity slip by. My hands itched to type, but I forced a smile, torn between the family I was trying to belong to and the cause I was fighting for.
